content.description: A harder route that uses only the orange-ish face found right of the V1 Dihedral route. There are three distinct cracks running horizontally accross this face. The trick to this route is that those vertical cracks work better as underclings than crimps.
content.location: Found just to the right of V1 Dihedral. Look for three horizontal cracks.

content.description: Vertical face climbing following a thin vertical crack. There is evidence of two bolts for this route, but they have been broken off, and there is no evidence of any fixed anchors at the top for this route. If you need a challenge, here's the route for you.
content.location: In the middle of the wall, left of the Veasy, right of the V3 Quality Route.

content.description: Called "the best line here" onÂ  bookofboulders.com. It is definitely worth visiting this area for. Fun V3 that involves a small dyno. Look for small crimps and hidden ledges.
content.location: Right of Unknown Diherdal, Left of VHard

content.description: A dihedral route featuring a thin crack and a few crimps here and there. fall area is slightly slanted, but not too bad.
content.location: In the taller dihedral on the left side of the quarry.

content.description: A fun warm up route with a perfect landing area. Follow the arete, and avoid using the ledges in the dihedral to the right. Foot holds were marked with chalk as of 3/25/2020.
content.location: left of the old broken bolt face(VHard) and right of Whack Cracks.
Left of the VHard route, and right of the V0 Arete

content.description: A blocky arete with a terrible landing. The route is quite easy, but the crux is mental. After 6 feet the only option is to top out.
If you're stumped by VHard, then this route to the right acts as a consolation prize.
content.location: Just to the right of VHard

content.description: An East facing wall found on the backside of an outcropping of rock. The bouldering here is good quality with nice landings for most of the routes. Found out about this area through bookofboulders.com. There's evidence of old bolts, a top rope pole, and homeless people burning tires and sleeping there. The easy access and close proximity to town make this spot worth a visit for an hour or two. There appears to be an even bigger cliff further uphill to the East, but the complete lack of details on what looks like a beautiful Trad climbing cliff lead me to believe that the cliff in question is on private property.
